description:
From Middle English clucchen, clicchen, cluchen, clechen, cleken, from Old English clyċċan (“to clutch, clench”), from Proto-Germanic *klukjaną, from Proto-Germanic *klu- (“to ball up, conglomerate, amass”), from Proto-Indo-European *glew- (“to ball up; lump, mass”).
Cognate with Swedish klyka (“clamp, fork, branch”). The noun is from Middle English cleche, cloche, cloke ("claw, talon, hand"; compare Scots cleuk, cluke, cluik (“claw, talon”)), of uncertain origin, with the form probably assimilated to the verb.

Alternative etymology derives Old English clyċċan from Proto-Germanic *klēk- (“claw, hand”), from Proto-Indo-European *glēk-, *ǵlēḱ- (“claw, hand; to clutch, snatch”). If so, then cognate with Irish glac (“hand”).

entries.meaning: The claw of a predatory animal or bird. [from 13th c.]
(by extension) A grip, especially one seen as rapacious or evil. [from 16th c.]
A device to interrupt power transmission, commonly used to separate the engine and gearbox in a car. [from 19th c.]
examples: Hyponyms: centrifugal clutch, dog clutch, friction clutch

entries.meaning: The pedal in a car that disengages power and torque transmission from the engine (through the drivetrain) to the drive wheels.
Any device for gripping an object, as at the end of a chain or tackle.
A fastener that attaches to the back of a tack pin to secure an accessory to clothing. (See Clutch (pin fastener).)
A small handbag or purse with no straps or handle.

verbs.description: clutch (third-person singular simple present clutches, present participle clutching, simple past and past participle clutched)

entries.meaning: To seize, as though with claws. [from 14th c.]
To grip or grasp tightly. [from 17th c.]
examples: She clutched her purse tightly and walked nervously into the building.
Synonyms: clasp, grasp, grip; see also Thesaurus:grasp

entries.meaning: (video games) To win in a 1vX (one versus X) situation.
(video games, by extension) To unexpectedly or luckily succeed in a difficult activity.

description: Variant form of cletch, from Middle English cleken (“to hatch”), perhaps from Old Norse klekja (“to hatch”).

entries.meaning: A brood of chickens or a sitting of eggs. [from 18th c.]
A group or bunch (of people or things). [from 20th c.]

verbs.description: clutch (third-person singular simple present clutches, present participle clutching, simple past and past participle clutched)

description: Unknown; possibly analagous to clinch, pinch, which have similar senses.

adjectives.description: clutch (comparative more clutch, superlative most clutch)

entries.meaning: (US, Canada) Performing or tending to perform well in difficult, high-pressure situations.
